content: The "Responsible Government Act of 1993" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. The Congress emphasizes the importance of citizen participation in government, the need for public officials to serve responsibly without personal gain or foreign influence, and the establishment of proper conduct and accountability in government. The Congress stresses citizen participation, responsible service without personal gain or foreign influence, and the need for proper conduct and accountability in government, including the creation of a uniform code of ethics for all officials. The Congress emphasizes citizen participation, responsible service without personal gain or foreign influence, and the need for proper conduct and accountability in government, including the establishment of a uniform code of ethics for all officials. The Act aims to ensure the integrity of the Federal Government and its officials, restore public confidence in elected officials, and prohibit certain individuals from holding specific positions. The Act prohibits delegates to Congress from representing foreign governments or unregistered corporations for pay. It also restricts individuals who have served in government or military positions from lobbying for foreign interests for at least 2 years after leaving office. To prevent undue influence, individuals who have worked in the government are prohibited from lobbying for any interest except their own before the executive or legislative branches for a certain period after leaving office. This measure aims to ensure transparency and protect public figures from unfounded accusations. All senior level executive and legislative officials and employees must file financial disclosure forms, which will be public record to protect public figures from rumors and unfair accusations. Section 3(g) of the Act is amended to include "in any existing proceeding or criminal or civil law enforcement inquiry or investigation". SEC. 5. RESTRICTIONS ON REPRESENTING FOREIGN PRINCIPALS. Section 207(f) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include permanent restrictions on officers or employees who represent a foreign principal or aid them in influencing decisions of US officials after their service ends. Offenders will be punished as provided in section 216 of this title. The restrictions in section 207(f) of title 18, US Code, apply to certain officers and employees who participate in trade or treaty negotiations on behalf of the United States or have access to exempt information. The restrictions in section 207(f) of title 18, US Code apply to officers and employees involved in trade or treaty negotiations on behalf of the United States, including those with access to exempt information designated by the department or agency. The term 'foreign entity' refers to a foreign government or political party, while 'foreign principal' is defined in the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938. The amendment to section 207(f) of title 18, US Code imposes a two-year restriction on officers and employees of the US government, prohibiting them from representing a foreign entity with the intent to influence a decision of any US department or agency within 2 years of leaving their position. The restrictions in section 207(f) of title 18, US Code apply to individuals whose government service ends on or after the enactment of the Act, prohibiting them from aiding foreign entities to influence US government decisions. The restrictions in section 207(f) of title 18, US Code apply only to participation in trade or treaty negotiations and access to information occurring after the date of enactment. SEC. 6. FIVE-YEAR BAN ON ANY LOBBYING. Section 207 of title 18, United States Code is amended to increase the penalties for certain offenses from a two-year to a five-year ban on lobbying. In section 207 of title 18, United States Code, penalties for certain offenses are increased from a two-year to a five-year ban on lobbying. This change includes extending the time frame in subsection (d)(1) and (e) from 1 year to 5 years. SEC. 7. Broaden disclosure requirements. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to adjust pay levels for certain government officials in the Executive, Military, and Legislative branches. This includes changes to pay grades and rates for officers in the Armed Forces serving on the staff of a general or flag officer. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to adjust pay levels for certain government officials in the Executive, Military, and Legislative branches, including specific positions such as Chief of Staff, Legislative Director, and Legal Counsel. SEC. 8. FORFEITURES OF ANNUITY OR RETIRED PAY. Section 8312 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for individuals convicted of specific offenses before, on, or after the date of enactment of the Responsible Government Act of 1993. Section 8312 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for individuals convicted of specific offenses before, on, or after the date of enactment of the Responsible Government Act of 1993. This applies to individuals convicted of criminal offenses involving acting as a foreign agent without registering or filing a financial disclosure form as required by Federal law. Individuals convicted of criminal offenses involving acting as a foreign agent and filing a false financial disclosure form in violation of Federal law will be affected by the amendments to Section 8312 of title 5, United States Code.
